title.rendered: Movistar will no longer be able to block these 85 pirate IPTV websites to watch football

content.rendered:
In 2020, shortly before the lockdown, a judge allowed the IPTV pirate websites, such as those to watch football, can be quickly identified and blocked without the need for judicial intervention. Movistar was responsible for drawing up a list of web pages that the rest of the operators have to block immediately.

Well, this judicial authorization has expired, which means that Movistarand therefore the rest of the operators that depended on their listings, will no longer be able to block pirate IPTV websites to watch football.

Movistar could block pirate IPTV websites

Under the original court order, Movistar sent weekly lists of URLs, domains and IP addresses to the operators, who were obliged to block said content within a maximum period of three hours, without the need for said pirated content to be authorized by a judicial authority. some. “This part of the measure will be valid for the duration of three sports seasons, that is, until May 25, 2022,” the resolution indicated, so the first websites included in the sentence can no longer be blocked.

pirate football

Another 41 websites will be unblocked in June

Since the ruling, the system has been operating in the same way, publishing at the end of last year a second large list that included another 41 pirate websites, in this case thanks to the lawsuit filed jointly in court by Movistar+ and LaLiga, which raised a total of 85 pirate websites that have suffered the consequences of this system.

LaLiga vs pirate football

In this case, the judicial authorization will expire next This difference is due to the fact that the first sentence mentioned May 25 as the limit, while the second referred to the “end of the season scheduled for June 19, 2022”.

CCCAM will continue to be blocked by Movistar

Movistar will not lose the power to block CCCAM, one of the systems used for pirate football via satellite. CCCAM, which stands for Client Card Conditional Module, is a protocol that decodes encrypted satellite signals by receiving the necessary “keys” over the Internet. In Spain, the installation of pirate decos had skyrocketed with this implemented system that allowed to see Movistar Plus+ in the same way as legitimate customers by satellite.

CCCAM

To combat this, Movistar sends empty or erroneous ECMs (Entitlement Control Messages) just before sending the correct ones, which blocks the service in pirate decoders, but does not affect the operation of its clients’ satellite decoders.

With the unblocking until further complaint or judicial authorization, the alternative to CCCAM’s malfunction will once again be to buy pirated IPTV lists to watch Movistar’s pay channels and other platforms, which will mean a new chapter in the eternal wheel of piracy.
